document.p: IPv4 Port forwarding allows you to forward incoming Internet traffic arriving on a specific port to an internal IPv4 address.
For example: if you are running a web server and the receives a request on port 80, this request should be forwarded to your web server.

The target device of the port forwarding rules will be specified by an address. Make sure that your device uses a fixed address. If you do not do this, the device might get a new address after some time and the port forwarding rule will no longer

For more information, see Static leases
This section is not available when the device is switched to bridged mode..
The IPv4 port forwarding table provides the following information:
document.li1:
Name
The name assigned to this port forwarding rule.

Protocol
The protocol used to transmit the message.

WAN port:
The port on which the incoming message will arrive.
You can also type in (a part of) the name of the application or service (e.g. HTTP). The will then display a list of services with such a name. If you then click one of the results, the will insert the corresponding port number (e.g. 80).

LAN port
The port to which the incoming message will be forwarded.

Destination IP
The IP address to which the incoming message will be forwarded.
You can also type in (a part of) the host name of the device. The will then display a list of devices with such a host name. If you then click one of the results, the will insert the corresponding IPv4 address.
document.h4: Adding new IPv4 port forwarding mapping
document.p: Under the IPv4 Port forwarding table, click Add new port mapping
